name: Mattel Electronics Aquarius Logo
description: A Logo interpeter that was loaded from a cartridge

commands.description: Not a perfect translation because any takes a list as a single parameter.  and operates with 2 or more parameters.  More can be learned at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n159/mode/2up

Not a perfect translation because any takes a list as a single parameter.  or operates with 2 or more parameters.  More can be learned at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n161/mode/2up
Draws a dot at the current turtle location.  circle 1 would be similar in WebLogo.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n171/mode/2up

e is short for East.  jumpRight is similar in WebLogo except that it appears Aquarius ignores current heading when running e.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n171/mode/2up

f is short for forward.  I'm not sure if there is a difference between f and fd.  I'm assuming f doesn't draw a line but that isn't clear from the Aquarius manual and I have no way to run the interpreter to test it.  The command is documented at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n181/mode/2up
Similar to setHeading towards :parameter1 in WebLogo.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n181/mode/2up

Similar to both heading and setHeading.  It means either one depending on if the parameter is a question mark or a number.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n183/mode/2up
Very similar to the item command except the parameters are swapped.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n193/mode/2up
Sets background color of the graphics screen to a number.  The numbers likely won't match the color numbers from WebLogo but setScreenColor is a very similar command.

Could be translated to WebLogo commands like penDown, penUp, or penDown?.  It depends on if the parameter passed to it is ? or a number.  pen 0 translates to penDown. pen 1 translates to penUp.  pen ? tranlsates to something like not penDown? except it needs to return 0 or 1 instead of false and true.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n195/mode/2up
prints but does not break line like WebLogo's print command
prints and breaks line like WebLogo's print command
rc is short for read character.  There is no similar command in WebLogo at the time of typing this.  Learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n199/mode/2up

rl is short for 'read list'.  There is no similar command in WebLogo at the time of writing this.  More can be learned at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n201/mode/2up.

s is short for south.  It looks like the most similar command would be jumpBackward except that s ignores the current heading of the turtle.  More can be learned at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n205/mode/2up

ss is short for splitscreen.  splitscreen is supported by WebLogo's command input box but not as an official command that can be run in procedures or from the code editor. More can be learned at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n209/mode/2up

thing reads the value of a variable.  WebLogo has no similar command.  In WebLogo, you read a variable using the colon such as :x for reading a variable named x.  It looks like thing is for reading arbitrary variable names.  For example, make "x 4 make y "x print thing :y would print 4.  It is a bit like treating variables as pointers.  You can learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n209/mode/2up
Returns a turtle name.  Since WebLogo uses only 1 turtle, there is no similar command.  You can learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n213/mode/2up

w is short for west.  It is similar to jumpLeft except that w ignores the turtle's current heading.  You can learn more at https://archive.org/details/mattel-electronics-aquarius-logo/page/n217/mode/2up
